thread.title: Cruise industry dreams of sailing into Cuba - MarketWatch
thread.title_full: Cruise industry dreams of sailing into Cuba - MarketWatch

author: Charles Passy
title: Cruise industry dreams of sailing into Cuba - MarketWatch
text:
Now that the U.S. flag is flying again in Cuba , could boatloads of American cruise passengers soon be bound to the island nation?
Certainly, the cruise industry is considering that possibility.
In a recently televised interview with Miami’s CBS affiliate, newly appointed Norwegian Cruise Line NCLH, +0.02% Chief Executive Frank Del Rio said: “We have itineraries in my upper right-hand drawer ready to go. People want to go to Cuba.”
The obstacle, of course, is that U.S. restrictions still prevent travel to Cuba purely for tourism. President Obama’s 2014 announcement of an easing of travel restrictions applied to those seeking to make their way to the island nation for other reasons, including visiting family. In essence, a lifting of the embargo would be necessary to fully open Cuba to Americans.
Scientists discover new Jupiter-like planet (1:04) Scientists have discovered a Jupiter-like planet in a solar system outside our own. It's called 51 Eridani b and is 100 light years away.
But if such a day were to come, the business could be sizable, with the American Society of Travel Agents estimating that more than 500,000 American cruise travelers would visit Cuba within the first two years. (Another 1 million leisure travelers would come by air, the ASTA notes.)
Still, the obstacles for the cruise industry aren’t just those involving U.S. policy. The fact remains that Cuban ports aren’t necessarily equipped to handle the mammoth ships that have come to define cruise travel.
“There are a number of factors for consideration before a cruise line would commit to adding a destination to an itinerary,” said the Cruise Line Industry Association in a statement after President Obama’s December announcement.
NCL’s Del Rio argues that if cruise ships could travel to Cuba, the beneficiaries would go beyond cruise lines or vacationers. He says Florida’s economy would also benefit since the added number of travelers would likely necessitate the expansion of local ports.
“The impact will not just be on the infrastructure in Cuba, but also the infrastructure in Miami,” he said in the televised interview.
This story was updated on Aug. 14, 2015 .
